article:
We shouldn't get distracted by the U.S. president. The mob that attacked the Capitol is part of a global movement that will survive him – in America and here in Europe.
Lesen Sie diesen Text auf Deutsch
It is true that a simple one-to-one
comparison between political dynamics in the United States and Europe is
impossible. That is especially true of the right wing and right-wing radical
movements, which have completely different traditions and influences in the
U.S. than do their European counterparts. Religion, the welfare state,
homosexuality – positions on those issues tend to be diametrically opposed
among right-wingers on opposing sides of the Atlantic. And a figure like Donald Trump would likely have trouble generating much of a following in Europe, just
as Viktor Orbán would be similarly shunned in the U.S.
Still, the storming of the U.S. Capitol
isn't purely an American affair. The political desolation in the U.S. was
triggered by the same storm that is also raging in Europe.
The attack of violent Trump followers on U.S.
lawmakers last Wednesday was the most striking operation thus far seen from a
global movement which, despite the personality cult that has developed around
the U.S. president, would continue to grow even if Trump would suddenly decide
to devote the rest of his life to fighting global warming. Trump only
cultivated and harvested that which has been successfully and rapidly growing
for quite some time in many other societies in the white West.
In the U.S. as in Europe, right-wing
extremists have increasingly radicalized and militarized in recent years, while
at the same time becoming frighteningly acceptable to milieus that are actually
much more moderate. These right-wing extremists, in the U.S. as in Europe, are
granted legitimacy far too often by opportunists within the democratic spectrum
– usually conservatives, but also economic liberals.
How great, really, is the difference
between U.S. Congressmen who repeat Trump's lies about election fraud, and
German politicians who allege that there is no true freedom of expression in
Germany? Both claims validate right-wing radical assertions that democratic norms
no longer exist. The logical conclusion drawn by many is that if democracy
doesn't exist, they then have the right to install one. With whatever means
necessary and against all resistance.
The result of this narrative, there as
here, is something which is the precise opposite of democracy: An element of
the societal center – plagued by fears of social decline and angered by demands
from marginalized groups to have a say – are willing to accept almost any political
narrative, even in the middle of a deadly pandemic, as long as it doesn't come
from the "establishment." Whether it be the sweeping rejection of
measures aimed at coronavirus protections or claims that a group of child
molesters is seeking to dominate the world and only Donald Trump is standing in
their way.
In Europe and the U.S., this narrative is
supplied by a well-oiled, attention-grabbing machinery made up of political market
criers, sect leaders, D-list celebrities and right-wing radicals who crop up as
real-estate moguls, ordinary bureaucrats, cabaret artists or intellectuals –
all of whom are following the same gospel: You, the silent white majority,
cannot rely on the mercy of your oppressors. You must take back your country.
And this gospel now dominates a significant portion of political life in many
Western societies.
Even if many radical right-wing politicians are now distancing themselves from the event -- including Jörg Meuthen, the co-head of the Alternative for Germany, who described Trump's speech in the run-up to the riots as "inexcusable" - what happened at the Capitol is consistent with this gospel and is closely related to that which right-wing extremists and their allies have been pursuing in Germany for some time: Symbolic land grabs and demonstrations of power against democratic institutions. The point of such
initiatives is to illustrate fantasies of the approaching revolution, to
produce an atmosphere of threatening urgency when paired with ominously kitschy
music in YouTube videos.
We saw that at the Reichstag in Berlin,
where right-wing radicals stormed up the steps to parliament in late August,
almost producing images similar to those seen in Washington, D.C. last week. In
Leipzig, too, where the violent nucleus of the corona-truthers overran the
police and forced their way into the city center. But the same thing happens in
much smaller situations, such as the recent corona protests in the small town
of Pössneck in the state of Thuringia, where a few dozen demonstrators were
able to briefly gain the upper hand against the police.
The fact that lawmakers and journalists
were forced to hide under tables, that an armed mob stormed up the stairs of
the Capitol and kicked in doors as Congress was in the process of certifying
the results of a democratic election, was yet another milestone for this
movement and its sympathizers – no matter if they are sitting in a trailer in
Utah or at home in the state of Brandenburg in Germany. The message to all of
these followers is the same: The final battle between us and the supposed
dictatorship is coming. Get ready, we can emerge victorious.
Yes, they feel like they can win. They sense
that they are having the kind of effect that they viewed as impossible just a
short time ago. They are feeling the "Winds of Change" – and such an
exalted feeling isn't one that others can easily destroy. As such, it will
prove impossible to slow this movement through compromise and reconciliation,
as many still apparently envision. From freedom fighter to mainstream voter: That is a path very few will take. And why should they?
The most unsettling thing isn't just the
right-wing radicals, but also those who tolerate them, here as in the U.S. Authoritarianism,
as we have learned from history, doesn't necessarily need majorities to retain
power or expand it. What it needs is fear among its opponents. Also helpful is
a growing feeling in the neutral center that an authoritarian takeover is
ultimately unavoidable and will then be lasting. And it needs security organs
that are prepared to join it in bending the constitution in times of crisis.
And with that, we have arrived at the next problem.
In this aspect too, the attack on the
Capitol was a signal. It could very easily have turned out to be a demoralizing
event for the right wing. If, for example, the state had clamped down
sufficiently to intimidate or even humiliate the mob. If the attack had
produced images of Trump followers handcuffed on the ground or fleeing the
police. If, for example, the images from last Wednesday had been similar to
those produced last summer when the U.S. president scandalously had peaceful Black Lives Matter demonstrators beaten and driven off just so he could pose with a Bible
in front of a church.
On this occasion, though, faced with a
violent right-wing mob of wannabe insurgents, there was no sign of a highly
militarized, highly motivated police force. Security personnel weren't just
grotesquely unprepared. They also pursued a strikingly lenient approach. The
images of violent perpetrators who were amicably helped out of the building
instead of being led away in handcuffs, or the pictures of assailants taking
selfies with the police, are an additional message from the right-wing
radicals. It is a message intended for their opponents: Are you certain that
your police will protect you when things get serious?
Here, too, there are parallels between the
United States and Europe. The security apparatuses, the armies, the secret
services, the police forces – let's be honest: Thus far, their assistance
against the authoritarian wave has been limited at best. In Germany, the many
reports of disappearing ammunition, secret prepper networks and racist WhatsApp
groups are cause for serious concern. And Washington has now shown with
disconcerting clarity how close right-wing radicals can come to realizing their
overthrow fantasies if the police merely declines to confront them with the
severity required.
There is also hope, of course. It was also
present on that terrible day in Washington last week. It was the news that the
state of Georgia, long under Republican control, had followed up its support of
Joe Biden in the presidential election by electing two Democratic Senators,
thus handing Biden a majority in the Senate as well.
The deeper message of this result goes far
beyond the changing of the guard in the Senate. The victory in Georgia was made
possible because the Black Democratic activist Stacey Abrams and her team have
spent years mobilizing Black voters in the states – voters who had for years
faced numerous hurdles designed to prevent them from participating.
We shouldn't forget: As frightening and
powerful as nationalist authoritarians look, they are a minority and they are
on the defensive. They are afraid of societies where groups that have thus far
been marginalized are given an equal voice. They know that they only have a
chance when those people who are victims of their racism are not heard, don't
vote and don't participate in political life. If they are heard, if they do
participate, then the situation drastically changes, in the U.S. as in Europe.
That is the opportunity we have to end the
advance of right-wing radicalism: a more open society that doesn't constantly
listen to the clamor of the right wing, working instead to ensure that all have
avenues to political and societal participation. Democracy itself, in its truest
form, as a protector of minorities, is the best recipe against that which took
place in Washington. In both the U.S. and here in Europe.
Translated by Charles Hawley
